s.text: Rubin expressed hope that the Russians might succeed in "convincing the Serbs to turn around" and "accept our conditions."

The Russians have been part and parcel of our effort to try to find a peaceful solution."
Part of the indignity of negotiation is the implication that during the bargaining NATO will offer more and more concessions.

Confronted recently with a coarse question as to whether the United States was "willing to talk to Milosevic," Lockhart stonily replied, "The NATO alliance has made demands, and he needs to meet them."
While hitting Milosevic over the head, NATO is offering terms under which it is willing to stop.
When asked on Face the Nation whether the United States would "negotiate" with a "war criminal," Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott sternly replied: "We're not negotiating with Milosevic.
When asked whether "at some point" dealing with Milosevic would "become impossible," Lockhart scoffed, "I am not going to spell out a timetable or what he has to do."
When asked whether "at some point" dealing with Milosevic would "become impossible," Lockhart scoffed, "I am not going to spell out a timetable or what he has to do."

A few days ago, when a reporter asked about the N word, White House spokesman Joe Lockhart answered, "We have a military objective now, which is to bring President Milosevic to meet these conditions that we have laid out."
On Sunday's talk shows, pundits asked various U.S. officials how they could even "contemplate negotiating with Mr. Milosevic after what he's done."
